PT J
AN ZOOR15401004922
DT Article
TI New records of spiders (Araneae) from Portugal.
AU Lissner, Jorgen (lissner@nathist.dk) 
SO Arachnologische Mitteilungen
VL 54
PS 52-58
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Data about spiders collected in Portugal are presented. Two new species
   are described, Scotophaeus dolanskyi spec. nov. (Gnaphosidae) and
   Apostenus crespoi spec. nov. (Liocranidae). Three species are recorded
   for the first time in Portugal: Dysdera lata Wider, 1834 (Dysderidae),
   Scotophaeus validus (Lucas, 1846) and Euophrys nigripalpis Simon, 1937
   (Salticidae). Illustrations of two rarely illustrated species are also
   presented: Nigma hortensis (Simon, 1870) (Dictynidae) and Canariphantes
   zonatus (Simon, 1884) (Linyphiidae).
C1 Lissner, Jorgen; Nat Hist Museum Aarhus, Wilhelm Meyers Alle 210,Univ
   Pk, Aarhus, DK-8000, Denmark, Denmark.
EM lissner@nathist.dk
SC Zoology
SN 1018-4171
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Apostenus crespoi; Scotophaeus dolanskyi [Portugal /  / New species]. 
   Araneae; Dysdera lata; Euophrys nigripalpis; Scotophaeus validus
   [Portugal /  / New record; systematics]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Araneae (Arachnida): [New record]. 
   Apostenus crespoi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Portugal, P. 55]. 
   Dysdera lata - Reuss 1834 (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Euophrys nigripalpis - Simon 1937 (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Scotophaeus dolanskyi (Araneae): [Sp nov, Portugal, P. 53]. 
   Scotophaeus validus - (Lucas 1846) (Araneae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401004907
DT Article
TI Notes on Afrotropical Pyrgodesmidae, 3 (Diplopoda: Polydesmida).
AU Golovatch, S.I.
   Fiemapong, A.R. Nzoko
   VandenSpiegel, D.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 26
IS 3
PS 175-215
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eleven new species of Pyrgodesmidae are described: Monachodesmus
   bamboutos sp.n., M. bipindi sp.n., M. awae sp.n., M. yabassi sp.n., M.
   bagam sp.n., M. djawara sp.n. and M. minutus sp.n., all from Cameroon,
   Cryptocorypha dimorpha sp.n., C. monomorpha sp.n., C. bocal sp.n. and C.
   leleupi sp.n., all from the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The former
   five species, together with Monachodesmus longicaudatus Golovatch, Nzoko
   Fiemapong et VandenSpiegel, 2015, for which new records from Cameroon
   and new illustrations of the gonopods are provided, form the
   longicaudatus group characterized by the long paramedian caudal lobes on
   segment 19 fully concealing the telson from above. A key is given to all
   six species of the group. Both Afrocorypha Loksa, 1967 and
   Procoptodesmus Brolemann, 1920 are formally synonymized with
   Cryptocorypha Attems, 1907, syn.n.; the latter genus is reviewed and
   redefined, with a key provided to all six African species known to date.
   These include also C. nympha Loksa, 1967, a poorly described species
   from the Republic of the Congo, as well as C. diffusa (Brolemann, 1920),
   comb. n.ex Procoptodesmus, which is redescribed and richly illustrated,
   based on unpublished material from Tanzania.
C1 Golovatch, S.I.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Problems Ecol & Evolut, Leninsky
   Prospekt 33, Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.
RI Golovatch, Sergei/J-7036-2018
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Cryptocorypha [Afrotropical region /  / Key to species].

   Monachodesmus awae; Monachodesmus bagam; Monachodesmus bamboutos;
   Monachodesmus bipindi; Monachodesmus djawara; Monachodesmus minutus;
   Monachodesmus yabassi [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
   Monachodesmus longicaudatus [Cameroon /  / New record]. 
   Monachodesmus longicaudatus species group [Cameroon /  / Key to
   species]. 
   Pyrgodesmidae [Afrotropical region /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Diplopoda
OR Cryptocorypha - Attems 1907 (Diplopoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 213; Syn

   1920, p. 210; Key to species, Afrotropical region, P. 214].

   Cryptocorypha leleupi (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 207]. 
   Cryptocorypha monomorpha (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 203]. 
   Monachodesmus awae (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 185]. 
   Monachodesmus bagam (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 191]. 
   Monachodesmus bamboutos (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 176]. 
   Monachodesmus bipindi (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 183]. 
   Monachodesmus djawara (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 193]. 
   Monachodesmus longicaudatus - Golovatch et al. 2015 (Diplopoda): [First
   time figured, Gonopods, p. 179; New record]. 
   Monachodesmus longicaudatus species group (Diplopoda): [Key to species,
   Cameroon, P. 191]. 
   Monachodesmus minutus (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 195]. 
   Monachodesmus yabassi (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 187]. 
   Procoptodesmus diffusus - Brolemann 1920 (Diplopoda): [Referred to,
   Cryptocorypha, p. 210]. 
   Pyrgodesmidae (Diplopoda).

AN ZOOR15401004913
DT Article
TI Further notes on Napoca Simon, 1901, the genus of beetle-like jumping
   spiders (Aranei: Salticidae), with a description of a new species.
AU Logunov, Dmitri V. (dmitri.v.logunov@manchester.ac.uk) 
   Schaefer, Michael
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 26
IS 3
PS 233-240
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The poorly known genus Napoca Simon, 1901 is redefined and diagnosed. A
   new species, Napoca constanzeae sp.n. (#) from Andalusia (Spain), is
   diagnosed and described. The unknown female of Napoca insignis (O.
   Pickard-Cambridge, 1872) is described for the first time. A
   distributional map for both species is provided.
C1 Logunov, Dmitri V.; Univ Manchester, Manchester Museum, Oxford Rd,
   Manchester, Lancs, M13 9PL, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM dmitri.v.logunov@manchester.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X

   Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Napoca [Africa / Mediterranean region / Distribution; systematics]
   [Eurasia /  / ]. 
   Napoca constanzeae [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Napoca - Simon 1901 (Araneae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 234]. 
   Napoca constanzeae (Araneae): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 237]. 
   Napoca insignis - Pickard-Cambridge 1872 (Araneae): [First time
   described, Female, p. 238].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401004910
DT Article
TI New data on Aituaria pontica (Spassky, 1932) (Aranei: Nesticidae).
AU Esyunin, Sergei L. (Esyunin@psu.ru) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 26
IS 3
PS 241-243
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Aituaria Esyunin et Efimik, 1998 is redefined as monotypic. It
   is close to the predominantly Caucasian borutzkyi species group of the
   genus Carpathonesticus Lehtinen et Saaristo, 1980, but can easily be
   distinguished from it by the broad, ribbon-shaped embolus notched at its
   tip, as compared to the narrow, tapering off embolus in the borutzkyi
   species group. The species Aituaria nataliae Esyunin et Efimik, 1998 is
   synonymized with A. pontica (Spassky, 1932). A. pontica is reported from
   the Middle Urals for the first time, its male palp is illustrated and
   distributional and ecological data are also summarized.
C1 Esyunin, Sergei L.; Perm State Univ, Bukireva St 15, Perm, 614600,
   Russia, Russia.
EM Esyunin@psu.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia
DE Aituaria pontica [Eurasia /  / Distribution; new record; systematics]
   [Russia / Middle Urals / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Aituaria - Esyunin & Efimik 1998 (Araneae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 241].
   
   Aituaria pontica - (Spassky 1932) (Araneae): [Syn nov, Aituaria natali
   Esyunin & Efimik 1998, p. 242; New record].

DT Article
TI Redescription of the holotype of Larinia vara Kauri, 1950 (Aranei:
   Araneidae) from South Africa, with establishing of a new combination.
AU Marusik, Yuri M. (yurmar@mail.ru) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 26
IS 3
PS 245-247
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The holotype male of Larinia vara Kauri, 1950 known only from
   Kwazulu-Natal is redescribed. It was found that species does not belong
   to Larinia Simon, 1874 or any other genera of Mangorini. Judging from
   the somatic characters it is most close to Atea C.L. Koch, 1837, a genus
   currently considered as junior synonym of Araneus Clerk, 1757 sensu
   lato. Because of this a new combination Araneus varus (Kauri, 1950)
   comb.n. is suggested.
C1 Marusik, Yuri M.; RAS, Inst Biol Problems North, Portovaya Str 18,
   Magadan, Russia, Russia.
EM yurmar@mail.ru
RI Marusik, Yuri/D-5701-2018
OI Marusik, Yuri/0000-0002-4499-5148
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Araneus varus - (Kauri 1950) (Araneae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Larinia, p. 245]. 
   Larinia vara - Kauri 1950 (Araneae): [Redescription, Holotype, p. 246;
   Referred to, Araneus, p. 245].

AN ZOOR15401005123
DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the oribatid mite genus Brassiella
   (Acari: Oribatida: Caloppiidae).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Liao, Jhih-Rong
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 72
IS 9
PS 1041-1048
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The oribatid mite genus Brassiella (Oribatida, Caloppiidae) is recorded
   for the first time from Taiwan. A new species of this genus is described
   from leaves of Tabebuia chrysantha of Qiaotou Sugar Factory; Brassiella
   taiwanica Ermilov sp. n. differs from all other species by the following
   combination of morphological traits: lamellae not reaching insertions of
   lamellar setae; lamellar setae dilated mediodistally, interlamellar
   setae leaf-shaped, bothridial setae globose; twelve pairs of notogastral
   setae developed, p3 vestigial, p1 and p2 minute, other setae short,
   leaf-shaped; adanal lyrifissures located in horizontal position; leg
   solenidia [phi] on tibiae IV swollen distally. New generic diagnosis and
   an identification key to the known species of Brassiella are provided.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
OI Liao, Jhih-Rong/0000-0003-1234-2350
SC Zoology
SN 0006-3088
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Brassiella [Taiwan /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Brassiella taiwanica [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Brassiella - Balogh 1970 (Acari): [Emended diagnosis, P. 1041; Key to
   species, P. 1047; New record]. 
   Brassiella taiwanica - Ermilov 2017 (Acari): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 1042].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401005127
DT Article
TI Alburnoides economoui, a new species of spirlin from Central Greece and
   redescription of Alburnoides thessalicus (Actinopterygii: Cyprinidae).
AU Barbieri, Roberta (robertab@hcmr.gr) 
   Vukic, Jasna
   Sanda, Radek
   Kapakos, Yiannis
   Zogaris, Stamatis
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 72
IS 9
PS 1075-1088
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Until recently all the Alburnoides populations of the Macedonia-Thessaly
   and Western Aegean ecoregions were considered as Alburnoides bipunctatus
   thessalicus Stephanidis, 1950. Here a new species of spirlin,
   Alburnoides economoui, is described from the Spercheios River (Fthiotida
   Prefecture). It is distinguished from all other congeners in Greek river
   basins and the Danube and Elbe drainages by the combination of the
   following characters: a very sharp ventral keel, scaleless or with 1-2
   scales; 121/2-141/2 branched anal-fin rays; 42-47 + 1-3 pored lateral
   line scales; 19-25 pre-dorsal scales; snout conical, slightly pointed;
   snout length shorter than eye diameter; pelvic-fin origin about midway
   between pectoral-fin and anal-fin origins or slightly closer to anal-fin
   origin. The name Alburnoides thessalicus is now restricted to the
   populations from the Pinios, Aliakmon and Axios/Vardar rivers. A
   redescription and designation of neotype for Alburnoides thessalicus is
   provided. The species can be distinguished from all other congeners in
   Greek river basins and the Danube and Elbe basins by the presence of a
   sharp ventral keel in only 2/3 of its length, variably scaled with
   modally 4-6 scales; usually 121/2 branched anal-fin rays; 44-50 + 1-2
   pored lateral line scales; 24-31 pre-dorsal scales; snout stout,
   slightly to clearly rounded; snout length about equivalent to the eye
   diameter; pelvic-fin origin closer to anal-fin origin than to
   pectoralfin. Despite similar morphological characters when compared to
   other European Alburnoides species, A. economoui differs remarkably
   genetically from all other studied Alburnoides species. The
   interspecific genetic divergence based on cytochrome b nucleotide
   sequences ranges from 7.3 to 8.8% (uncorrected p-distance).
C1 Barbieri, Roberta; Hellen Ctr Marine Res, Inst Marine Biol Resources &
   Inland Waters, Athens, 19013, Greece, Greece.
EM robertab@hcmr.gr
RI Vukic, Jasna/D-2811-2015
OI Vukic, Jasna/0000-0003-2243-0303
SC Zoology
SN 0006-3088
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Alburnoides economoui [Greece /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Alburnoides economoui - Barbieri, Vukic, Sanda & Zogaris 2017
   (Cyprinidae): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 1077]. 
   Alburnoides thessalicus - Stephanidis 1950 (Cyprinidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 1081; Redescription, P. 1082]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15401005127

TI Lepidoptera from the Pantepui. Part IV. New Riodinidae Riodininae and
   Pieridae Pierinae.
FT Lepidoptera del Pantepui. Parte IV. Nuevos Riodinidae Riodininae y
   Pieridae Pierinae
AU Costa, Mauro (mauro13x50@gmail.com) 
   Viloria, Angel L.
   Attal, Stephane
   Neild, Andrew F.E.
   Fratello, Steven A.
   Callaghan, Curtis
   Gallard, Jean-Yves
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 122
IS 3
PS 269-286
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species and one new subspecies of butterflies (Lepidoptera,
   Papilionoidea) from the Pantepui (Venezuela, Guyana) are described:
   Pirascca hanneri Gallard, Viloria, Fratello & Costa, n. sp. (Riodinidae,
   Riodininae, Symmachiini); Melanis dulcis Callaghan & Costa, n. sp.
   (Riodinidae, Riodininae, Riodinini); Melete leucadia reyi Neild & Costa,
   n. ssp. (Pieridae,Pierinae, Pierini). Ancyluris lais (Boisduval), 1870,
   stat. rest. (Riodinidae,Riodininae, Riodinini) is reinstated as a
   distinct species.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Belomantis Giglio-Tos, 1914 (Mantodea,
   Toxoderidae).
FT Revision du genre Belomantis Giglio-Tos, 1914 (Mantodea, Toxoderidae).
AU Roy, Roger (roger.roy@mnhn.fr) 
   Stiewe, Martin B.D.
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 122
IS 3
PS 287-295
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB In 1914, the genus Belomantis was created by Ermanno Giglio-Tos with the
   type species B. helenae on the basis of a pair from Northern Rhodesia
   (today Zambia) deposited in the Zoological Museum of Naples. In this
   description he also mentions a female of the same species from Atakpame,
   Togo, from the Berlin collection, which during our research turned out
   to be a new species. We also uncovered that the original types are most
   likely lost as it was not possible to detect the specimens in the Naples
   Museum, which suffered the loss of several specimens by destruction
   during the World Wars. Therefore, we are designing a neotype for
   Belomantis helenae, now deposited in the collection of Vienna. Since the
   first description of Giglio-Tos, various authors frequently mixed up
   Belomantis and Calamothespis Werner, 1907, which is the most closely
   related genus. Specimens of one genus were often wrongly attributed to
   the other. Belomantis and Calamothespis belong to the tribe
   Calamothespini Giglio-Tos, 1914. Belomantis can be distinguished from
   Calamothespis by the very elongated last segment of the cerci, its
   elongated apical lobes of mid femora, and a different male genitalia
   structure, especially in the phalloid apophysis. Furthermore, Belomantis
   is featuring more anterior fore tibiae spines and a stronger pattern on
   the fore and hind wings. Up to now, Belomantis was considered
   monospecific but after an examination of all available specimens we
   found two further new species: Belomantis mirei n. sp. (Cameroon) and B.
   occidentalis n. sp. (Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso and Togo), described,
   pictured and illustrated in this work. French and English keys to the
   species are provided.
C1 Roy, Roger; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Entomol, CP 50,57 Rue Cuvier, Paris,
   F-75231, France, France.
EM roger.roy@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Belomantis [Africa /  / Key to species]. 
   Belomantis helenae [Africa /  / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
   Belomantis mirei [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
   Belomantis occidentalis [Burkina /  / New species] [Ivory Coast /  / ]
   [Togo /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Mantodea
OR Belomantis - Giglio-Tos 1914 (Mantodea): [Revision, P. 287; Key to
   species, Africa, In French & English, p. 288]. 
   Belomantis helenae - Giglio-Tos 1914 (Mantodea): [Type material, P. 290;
   Neotype designated, P. 290; Redescription, P. 290]. 
   Belomantis mirei (Mantodea): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 291]. 
   Belomantis occidentalis (Mantodea): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 292]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15401004979

PT J
AN ZOOR15401004982
DT Article
TI A new species and new records of the genus Pertusius (Coleoptera,
   Brentidae, Acratini).
FT Une nouvelle espece et de nouvelles donnees pour le genre Pertusius
   (Coleoptera, Brentidae, Acratini).
AU Mantilleri, Antoine (amantill@mnhn.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 122
IS 3
PS 299-304
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Pertusius Mantilleri, 2016, P chamorroae n.
   sp., is described from Brazil, State of Rondonia (Porto Velho). New
   country records are provided for the following species: Pertusius
   apicalis (Sharp, 1895) (Panama), P errabundus (Kleine, 1927) (French
   Guiana, Bolivia, Costa Rica, Peru), P fidus (Kleine, 1927) (Bolivia) and
   P filum (Sharp, 1895) (Mexico). The females of P errabundus and P. fidus
   are described for the first time.

DT Article
TI The species of the genus Cephennium P. W. J. Muller & Kunze, subgenus
   Cephennium, of the French fauna (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Scydmaeninae).
FT Les especes du genre Cephennium P. W. J. Muller & Kunze, sous-genre
   Cephennium, de la faune de France (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Scydmaeninae).
AU Orousset, Jean (jorousset@sfr.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 122
IS 3
PS 311-356
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The French species of Scydmaeninae Cephenniini belonging to the genus
   Cephennium P. W. J. Muller & Kunze, 1822, subgenus Cephennium, are
   reviewed. Lectotypes are designated for C. albericum Croissandeau, 1894,
   C. argodi Croissandeau, 1891, C. intermedium Fairmaire, 1860, C.
   lantosquense Croissandeau, 1891, C. maritimum Reitter, 1884, and C.
   nicaense Reitter, 1882. Three species new for science are described: C.
   cauchoisi ri. sp., C. lefebvrei n. sp. and C. tronqueti n. sp.; a
   species, C. doderoi Binaghi, 1942, known from Italia, is new for France.
   The French fauna comprises now fourteen species; some comments about
   morphology, ecology, biology and distribution are provided.

TI Description of a new Tychius from Turkey (Coleoptera, Curculionidae,
   Curculioninae).
AU Weill, Patrick (p_weill@yahoo.fr) 
   Caldara, Roberto
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 122
IS 3
PS 359-362
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tychius colossus n. sp. from central Turkey is here described. Its
   habitus and type of vestiture keep it apart from other known species of
   the genus. It is thus temporarily included into the T intrusus group
   near the quite similar T trivialis Boheman, 1843, and T longiclava
   Hustache, 1937.

DT Article
TI CLASSIFICATION, NATURAL HISTORY, AND EVOLUTION OF THE ORTHOPLEURINAE
   (COLEOPTERA: CLERIDAE). PART VI. THE NEW GENERA COADNATUS OPITZ,
   FURCADIA OPITZ, AND LATUPUSILLUS OPITZ, ONE NEW SPECIES OF FUNICULA
   OPITZ, AND FOUR NEW SPECIES OF ROMANAECLERUS WINKLER.
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 421-433
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This work involves establishing the genera Coadnatus Opitz, new genus,
   Furcadia Opitz, new genus, and Latupusillus Opitz, new genus, and
   describing new species in the previously established genera Funicula
   Opitz and Romanaeclerus Winkler. Eight species are described: Coadnatus
   sakaii Opitz, new species, Funicula albocapilla Opitz, new species,
   Furcadia sandala Opitz, new species, Latupusillus laculatus Opitz, new
   species, Romanaeclerus dimidius Opitz, new species, Romanaeclerus
   gerstmeieri Opitz, new species, Romanaeclerus quadratus Opitz, new
   species, and Romanaeclerus vitellinus Opitz, new species. The concepts
   underlying the establishment of the genus category are discussed.
   Neorthopleurinae Opitz is synonymized with Orthopleurinae Boving and
   Craighead.

DT Article
TI EUBRIA MESOAMERICANA BARR AND SHEPARD (COLEOPTERA: PSEPHENIDAE:
   EUBRIINAE), A NEW PSEPHENID SPECIES FROM CENTRAL AMERICA WITH AN
   ENIGMATIC GENERIC DISTRIBUTION.
AU Barr, Cheryl B. (cbarr@berkeley.edu) 
   Shepard, William D.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 437-444
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eubria mesoamericana Barr and Shepard, new species, is described from
   Panama and Costa Rica, accompanied by images of the adult and larva and
   illustrations of the male genitalia. Habitat information is provided for
   the specimens collected by the authors. The discovery of a new species
   of Eubria Latreille in the Neotropics reveals a surprising geographic
   disjunction from its only congener in the Palearctic, Eubria palustris
   (Germar). Placement of the new species in the genus Eubria is supported
   by adult and larval morphological characters.
C1 Barr, Cheryl B.; Univ Calif Berkeley, Essig Museum Entomol, 1101 Valley
   Life Sci Bldg,4780, Berkeley, CA, 94720, USA, USA.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF CAMPTOCERUS DEJEAN, 1821 (COLEOPTERA: CURCULIONIDAE:
   SCOLYTINAE: SCOLYTINI) FROM ECUADOR.
AU Smith, Sarah M. (smith462@msu.edu) 
   Cognato, Anthony I.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 445-448
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Camptocerus lucwildi Smith and Cognato, new species is described from
   montane forests of the western slope of the Andes in Los Rios Province,
   Ecuador. The species is similar in morphology to Camptocerus quadridens
   Blackman, except that the male has one acute spine on the base of each
   elytron. This species represents one of the few species of Camptocerus
   Dejean known from the Tumbes-Choco-Magdalena forest.

TI DEFINITION AND REVISION OF THE SPUMARIUS SPECIES-GROUP OF NORTH AMERICAN
   PACHYBRACHIS CHEVROLAT (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE: CRYPTOCEPHALINAE).
AU Barney, Robert J. (rbarney@wvstateu.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 449-460
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB The spumarius species-group of Nearctic Pachybrachis Chevrolat, 1836 is
   defined and revised. The group is composed of one species: Pachybrachis
   spumarius Suffrian, 1852. A male specimen of P. spumarius, recently
   discovered in the Natural History Museum in London among some previously
   unrecognized type material of Suffrian, is herein designated as a
   lectotype. The synonymy of Pachybrachis roboris Fall, 1915 with P.
   spumarius is confirmed, and Pachybrachis obfuscatus Fall, 1915 is
   synonymized under P. spumarius, new synonymy. A description, figures,
   and range map are presented.
C1 Barney, Robert J.; West Virginia State Univ, Coll Nat Sci & Math,
   Institute, WV, 25112, USA, USA.
EM rbarney@wvstateu.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X

   Synonymy

   Chrysomelidae

   Pachybrachis spumarius Suffrian 1852, p. 455]. 
   Pachybrachis spumarius - Suffrian 1852 (Chrysomelidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 451; Redescription, P. 453; Senior synonym, Of
   Pachybrachis roboris Fall 1915, p. 455; Syn nov, Pachybrachys obfuscatus
   Fall 1915, p. 451].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF PSEUDACTIUM CASEY (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE:
   PSELAPHINAE) FROM TENNESSEE, USA.
AU Owens, Brittany E.
   Carlton, Christopher E.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 468-470
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Pseudactium credoi Owens and Carlton, new species, is described from
   three male specimens collected at a blacklight in Wilson County,
   Tennessee. Pseudactium credoi is similar to Pseudactium parabolicum
   (Brendel) and Pseudactium ursum Carlton in the form of the ventral
   projections of ventrite III, but secondary sexual modifications on the
   legs and the form of the aedeagus differ in ways that are consistent
   with species boundaries among other pselaphine taxa. A modified key to
   the species of Pseudactium Casey is provided to allow for the separation
   of P. credoi from the other twelve described species in the genus. This
   is the third species of Pseudactium described since the last revision of
   the genus.
C1 Owens, Brittany E.; Louisiana State Univ, Ctr Agr, 404 Life Sci Bldg,
   Baton Rouge, LA, 70803, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0010-065X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA
DE Pseudactium credoi [Tennessee /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Pselaphidae
OR Pseudactium - Casey (Pselaphidae): [Key to species, Modified to include
   new species, p. 470]. 
   Pseudactium credoi (Pselaphidae): [Sp nov, Tennessee, P. 469].

LA English
U1 0

AB Podolasia diabla Smith and Paulsen, new species and Podolasia parapilosa
   Smith and Paulsen, new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae:
   Podolasiini) are described from dune habitats in Coahuila, Mexico. The
   new species are illustrated, and diagnostic characters are discussed to
   separate them from previously described species. Podolasia diabla is
   notable as the first species known from this tribe with head horns.

DT Article
TI PHYLOGENETIC PLACEMENT OF ABRAEUS VIVIDULUS BROUN AND NOTES ON NEW
   ZEALAND HISTERIDAE (COLEOPTERA).
AU Leschen, Richard A.B. (Leschen@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
   Ohara, Masahiro
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 71
IS 3
PS 537-551
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Thomas Broun, the prolific New Zealand Coleopterist, described four
   species in the genus Abraeus Leach (Histeridae), two of which were
   placed in the genus Tribalus Erichson (Tribalus phylloides (Broun) is a
   junior synonym of Tribalus brouni (Broun), new synonymy), including one
   that is transferred to Parepierus Bickhardt (Parepierus brunneus
   (Broun), new combination). The fourth species, Abraeus vividulus Broun,
   was scored for 37 characters into a previously published data matrix,
   which demonstrated that a new genus-level status is required to
   accommodate the species. Brounhister Leschen and Ohara, new genus is
   named and the type species, Brounhister vividulus (Broun), new
   combination, is redescribed and placed in Abraeinae incertae sedis. A
   key to the New Zealand histerid genera is presented. Comments on
   histerid characters and the New Zealand fauna are included.
C1 Leschen, Richard A.B.; Landcare Res, New Zealand Arthropod Collect,
   Auckland, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM Leschen@landcareresearch.co.nz
OI Leschen, Richard/0000-0001-8549-8933
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0010-065X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Evolution;
   Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Histeridae [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [New Zealand /  / Key to genera]
   [ /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Hydrophiloidea,
   Histeridae
OR Histeridae (Hydrophiloidea): [Key to genera, New Zealand, P. 549]. 
   Abraeus brunneus - Broun 1881 (Histeridae): [Referred to, Parepierus, p.
   549]. 
   Abraeus vividulus - Broun 1880 (Histeridae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Brounhister, p. 543]. 
   Brounhister (Histeridae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Arabaeinae, Type
   species Abraeus vividulus Broun 1880, p. 543]. 
   Brounhister vividulus - (Broun 1880) (Histeridae): [Redescription, P.
   546; Comb nov, Transferred from Abraeus, p. 546]. 
   Parepierus brunneus - (Broun 1881) (Histeridae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Abraeus, p. 549].

DT Article
TI Identification of Blood Flukes Infecting Tiger Puffer Takifugu rubripes.
AU Ogawa, Kazuo (ogawak@kiseichu.org) 
   Liu, Shengfa
SO Fish Pathology
VL 52
IS 3
PS 131-140
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Blood flukes infecting tiger puffer Takifugu rubripes were re-examined
   taxonomically. Psettarium sp. TPC Ogawa et a/., 2007, Psettarium sp. TPJ
   Ogawa et al., 2007 and P. japonicum sensu Yamaguti, 1938 were analysed,
   together with the type specimens of P. sinense (Liu, 1997), originally
   recorded in Takifugu oblongus as Paradeontacylix sinensis Liu, 1997.
   Psettarium sp. TPC, represented by blood flukes from T. rubripes
   cultured in Dailian, China and those collected from T. rubripes imported
   from China and cultured in Kagawa Prefecture, Japan in 2005, were
   synonymized with P. sinense. Psettarium sp. TPJ, collected in 1993 from
   T. rubripes caught in Wakasa Bay, Fukui Prefecture and maintained in a
   cage for several months, was different from the congeners in the
   combination of having a large body size (larger than 7 mm long), a
   single testis extending posterior to the ovary, presence of anterior and
   posterior vasa deferentia, and is described here as P. wakasaense n. sp.
   A single museum specimen of P. japonicum sensu Yamaguti, 1938 collected
   from T. rubripes off Shanghai was morphologically distinguishable from
   most similar P. sinense in the dextral ovary, the female pore opening
   anterior to the cirrus pouch and absence of the testis on dextral side
   of the ovary, and is proposed here as P. yamagutii n. sp.
C1 Ogawa, Kazuo; Meguro Parasitol Museum, Tokyo, 1530064, Japan, Japan.
EM ogawak@kiseichu.org
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0388-788X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Psettarium [Piscean hosts / Takifugu rubripes / Systematics] [North
   Pacific / China & Japan / ]. 
   Psettarium wakasaense [Piscean hosts / Takifugu rubripes / New parasite
   species] [North Pacific / Japan / New species from piscean host]. 
   Psettarium yamagutii [Piscean hosts / Takifugu rubripes / New parasite
   species] [North Pacific / China, Shanghai / New species from piscean
   host]. 
   Takifugu rubripes [Digenean parasites / Psettarium wakasaense / New
   parasite species] [ / Psettarium yamagutii / ] [ / Psettarium / Parasite
   systematics] [North Pacific / China & Japan / ] [ / China, Shanghai /
   New platyhelminth parasite species] [ / Japan / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Tetraodontiformes, Tetraodontidae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Takifugu rubripes (Tetraodontidae): [Host]. 
   Psettarium (Digenea): [Parasite]. 
   Psettarium wakasaense (Digenea): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), Parasite of
   Takifugu rubripes (Pisces), p. 134; Parasite]. 
   Psettarium yamagutii (Digenea): [Sp nov, China, Shanghai (marine),
   Parasite of Takifugu rubripes (Pisces), p. 136; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Mitochondrial phylogeny and taxonomic status of the Capoeta damascina
   species group (Actinopterygii: Cyprinidae) in Iran with description of a
   new species.
AU Zareian, Halimeh
   Esmaeili, Hamid Reza (hresmaeili@shirazu.ac.ir) 
SO Iranian Journal of Ichthyology
VL 4
IS 3
PS 231-269
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The members of the genus Capoeta show an abstruse taxonomic status, a
   complex evolutionary history with the highest diversification in the
   Middle East and are closely related to the genus Luciobarbus. Our
   molecular and morphological results confirm the existence of eight
   species within the Capoeta damascina group in Iran. In this paper all
   eight recognized species are reviewed, and diagnoses are presented for
   all species. Capoeta birunii is considered as new species from
   Zayandehrud drainage basins. This species is distinguished from other
   small scaled Capoeta in the C. damascina group by a combination of
   morphological and molecular characters.
C1 Esmaeili, Hamid Reza; Shiraz Univ, Coll Sci, Shiraz, Iran, Iran.
EM hresmaeili@shirazu.ac.ir

   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology

   morphology; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia

   review] [General morphology /  / ] [Nucleic acids / mtDNA COI & cytb
   sequences / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Iran /  /
   Key to species] [ /  / distribution].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003964
DT Article
TI A new genus and new species of decapod crustacean (Decapoda: Brachyura:
   Panopeidae) from the early Priabonian (Late Eocene) of the central
   Pyrenees of Huesca (Aragon, Spain), with remarks on its habitat and
   ecology.
AU Osso, Alex (aosso@comt.cat) 
   Dominguez, Jose L.
SO Journal of Crustacean Biology
VL 37
IS 5
PS 602-607
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Eoacantholobulus oscensisn. gen, n. sp. is proposed to accommodate the
   decapods recovered in the early Priabonian outcrops of the central
   Pyrenees of Aragon (Spain). The strong similarities with the extant
   genera AcantholobulusFelder & Martin, 2003 and RhithropanopeusRathbun,
   1898 that the new taxon presents allow us, after detailed comparisons,
   to propose the placement of the new genus and new species in Panopeidae
   Ortmann, 1893, in particular in Panopeinae Ortmann, 1893, being the
   first record of this family in the Eocene of the Iberian Peninsula. The
   interpretation of the paleoenvironment inhabited by the new species,
   indicates that was very similar to the habitats where the extant
   panopeines inhabit. The different paleoenvironments inhabited by
   panopeines in the Tethyan and Atlantic waters of Europe, and in the
   Pacific and Atlantic waters of America during the Eocene times are
   discussed.
C1 Osso, Alex; 12-H,1r 1a, Tarragona, Catalonia, 43007, Spain, Spain.
EM aosso@comt.cat
OI Osso, Alex/0000-0003-2528-9915
SC Zoology
SN 0278-0372
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Eoacantholobulus [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Eoacantholobulus oscensis [Spain /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Eoacantholobulus (Brachyura): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Panopeinae, Type
   species Eoacantholobulus oscensis, p. 603, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Eoacantholobulus oscensis (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Spain, Eocene, P. 604;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI The mantis shrimps of the genus Raoulserenea Manning, 1995 (Crustacea:
   Stomatopoda: Pseudosquillidae) from French Polynesia, with the
   description of a new species and notes on its reproduction.
AU Ahyong, Shane T. (Ahyong@austmus.gov.au) 
   Caldwell, Roy L.
SO Journal of Crustacean Biology
VL 37
IS 5
PS 608-614
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Raoulserenea moorea n. sp. is described from French Polynesia based on
   specimens collected from inshore coral reefs. It is the smallest of the
   five species of the genus and further differentiated from congeners by
   the combination of a prominently angular rostral plate in adults, a
   uniform rather than reticulated colour pattern, and subtle features of
   the eyes, uropods, and telson. The new species is remarkable in
   Stomatopoda for its precocious development, and is possibly unique in
   becoming reproductive only one moult after postlarval settlement.
   Additional French Polynesian records of other species of Raoulserenea
   are reported, including the first documented records of R. oxyrhyncha
   (Borradaile, 1898) from the region. All species of the genus are now
   recorded from French Polynesia. A key to the species of Raoulserenea is
   provided and all species are figured in colour.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; Australian Museum, Res Inst, 1 William St, Sydney,
   NSW, 2010, Australia, Australia.
EM Ahyong@austmus.gov.au
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0278-0372
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Reproduction; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Raoulserenea [Reproduction /  / Systematics] [South Pacific / French
   Polynesia / ]. 
   Raoulserenea moorea [South Pacific / Society Islands / New species]. 
   Raoulserenea oxyrhyncha [South Pacific / French Polynesia / New record;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Hoplocarida, Stomatopoda
OR Raoulserenea - Manning 1995 (Stomatopoda): [Key to species, P. 613]. 
   Raoulserenea moorea (Stomatopoda): [Sp nov, Society Islands (marine), P.
   609]. 
   Raoulserenea oxyrhyncha - (Borradaile 1898) (Stomatopoda): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003966
DT Article
TI An updated classification of the freshwater crayfishes (Decapoda:
   Astacidea) of the world, with a complete species list.
AU Crandall, Keith A. (kcrandall@gwu.edu) 
   De Grave, Sammy
SO Journal of Crustacean Biology
VL 37
IS 5
PS 615-653
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 4
U2 34
AB The freshwater crayfishes are a group of decapod crustaceans that have
   played a critical role in a diversity of biological studies, from
   physiology, to ecology, neurobiology, conservation, and evolution.
   Central to many of these fields of study is the dependence on a robust
   taxonomic framework for accurate communication relating to species
   diversity and associated attributes. Despite a huge body of taxonomic
   work since Linnaeus, there has never been a single, comprehensive
   taxonomic summary of all the species of crayfish of the world. There has
   also been an abundance of recent taxonomic work in terms of new species
   descriptions and taxonomic insights gained from a variety of
   phylogenetic studies. Here we gather diverse taxonomic and phylogenetic
   information into a single resource. We develop an updated classification
   system that includes all the crayfishes worldwide and taxonomic changes
   to better reflect the current phylogenetic knowledge of the group. We
   also include all the fossil crayfish taxa for a complete classification
   of extant and extinct crayfishes. Our classification results in two
   superfamilies (Astacoidea and Parastacoidea), five families, 38 genera,
   and 669 species (692 including distinct subspecies). We provide a
   checklist of all species and include validated taxonomic authorities,
   type localities, figure references, and synonyms. We also provide
   arguments for our revised classification. The updated and complete
   classification aims to provide a robust framework for future studies of
   the freshwater crayfishes of the world.
C1 Crandall, Keith A.; George Washington Univ, Computat Biol Inst, SEH
   7000D,800 22nd St NW, Washington, DC, 20052, USA, USA.
EM kcrandall@gwu.edu
RI Crandall, Keith A./H-2789-2019
OI Crandall, Keith A./0000-0002-0836-3389
SC Zoology
SN 0278-0372
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Status; Documentation; Publications; Evolution; Zoogeography
DE Astacidea [Checklists / Updated world checklist / systematics]
   [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura

DT Article
TI Morphological study on a new opilionid species recorded from Turkey:
   Paranemastoma karolianus sp. n. (Opiliones: Nemastomatidae).
AU Ocal, Ilkay Corak (corakilkay@yahoo.com) 
   Bayram, Abdullah
   Yigit, Nazife
   Sancak, Zafer
SO Korean Journal of Applied Entomology
VL 56
IS 3
PS 241-247
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, a new opilionid species of Paranemastoma Redikorzevi,
   1936 is described from northern Turkey. Fine structures of extremities,
   dorsal integument and genitalia of Paranemastoma karolianus sp. n. are
   presented. Differences between the new species and related species are
   discussed.
C1 Ocal, Ilkay Corak; Univ Karatekin, Dept Biol, Cankiri, TR-18200, Turkey,
   Turkey.
EM corakilkay@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1225-0171
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Paranemastoma karolianus [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Paranemastoma - Redikorzevi 1936 (Opiliones): [Key to species, Males, p.
   242]. 
   Paranemastoma karolianus (Opiliones): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 242].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003426
DT Article
TI First record of a Northern Hawk-Owl Surnia ulula in the Black Forest.
FT Erster Nachweis einer Sperbereule Surnia ulula im Schwarzwald.
AU Pueschel, Hanspeter (hanspeter.pueschel@t-online.de) 
   Stark, Herbert
SO Ornithologische Beobachter
VL 114
IS 3
PS 201-208
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB From 23 November 2014 to 7 April 2015 a Northern Hawk-Owl was observed
   in the Northern Black Forest on the top of the Badener Hobe at around
   1000 m a.s.l. It was the 180th record for Germany, and the 8th for
   Baden-Wurttemberg. Only three records are known for Switzerland, and at
   least two for Alsace. Mice Apodemus sp. and Field Vole Microtus agrestis
   were confirmed as prey.
C1 Pueschel, Hanspeter; Goethestr 14, Offenburg, D-77654, Germany, Germany.
EM hanspeter.pueschel@t-online.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0030-5707
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Ecology; Predators; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Apodemus; Microtus agrestis [Avian predators / Surnia ulula / Predator
   prey record] [Germany / Scwharzwald / ]. 
   Surnia ulula [Mammalian prey / Apodemus / Predator prey record; new
   record] [ / Microtus agrestis / ] [Zoogeography /  / Records review]
   [France / Alsace / biology; distribution] [Germany / Baden-Wuerttemberg
   / ] [ / Scwharzwald / ] [Switzerland /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Strigiformes, Strigidae, Mammalia,
   Rodentia, Muridae
OR Surnia ulula (Strigidae): [Predator; New record]. 
   Apodemus (Muridae): [Prey]. 
   Microtus agrestis (Muridae): [Prey].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003027
DT Article
TI A new species Phlebopterum planicapitis from Madagascar (Hemiptera:
   Fulgoromorpha: Flatidae).
AU Swierczewski, Dariusz (dswier@ajd.czest.pl) 
   Stroinski, Adam
SO Polish Journal of Entomology
VL 86
IS 3
PS 275-291
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new planthopper species of the family Flatidae Phlebopterum
   planicapitis sp. n. endemic to Madagascar is described and illustrated.
   The species is limited to the north-western part of the island and is
   associated with coastal mangroves and riverside vegetation. A key to all
   the Phlebopterum species known from Madagascar is provided.
C1 Swierczewski, Dariusz; Jan Dlugosz Univ, Dept Biol & Nat Conservat, Al
   Armii Krajowej 13-15, Czestochowa, PL-42201, Poland, Poland.
EM dswier@ajd.czest.pl
OI SWIERCZEWSKI, DARIUSZ/0000-0001-5589-4388
SC Zoology
SN 0032-3780
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Phlebopterum [Madagascar /  / Key to species]. 
   Phlebopterum planicapitis [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Flatidae
OR Phlebopterum - Stal 1854 (Flatidae): [Key to species, Madagascar, P.
   284]. 
   Phlebopterum planicapitis (Flatidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 277].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003538
DT Article
TI New species of Haematoloechus (Digenea: Plagiorchioidea) parasiteof Rana
   spp. of southwestern Mexico.
AU Leon-Regagnon, Virginia (vleon@ib.unam.mx) 
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 88
IS 3
PS 555-559
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB During an inventory of the helminths of amphibians in Mexico, specimens
   of an undescribed species of Haematoloechus were collected from the
   lungs of Rana zweifeli and Rana sp. in southwestern Mexico. The
   objective of this study is to describe this species. The new species
   differsfrom other known species of Haematoloechus by the combination of
   the following characters: spindle shaped body, oral sucker/acetabulum
   ratio1: 0.31, longitudinal extracecal uterine loops to the level of
   posterior testis, ovary irregular, lobed and testes elongate, lobed. (C)
   2017 Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Instituto de Biologia.
C1 Leon-Regagnon, Virginia; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Biol, Apartado
   Postal 21, San Patricio, Jalisco, 48980, Mexico, Mexico.
EM vleon@ib.unam.mx
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Haematoloechus nicolasi [Amphibian hosts / Rana zweifeli / New parasite
   species] [ / Rana / ] [Mexico /  / New species from amphibian host]. 
   Rana; Rana zweifeli [Digenean parasites / Haematoloechus nicolasi / New
   parasite species] [Mexico /  / New platyhelminth parasite species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae,
   Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Rana (Ranidae): [Host]. 
   Rana zweifeli (Ranidae): [Host]. 
   Haematoloechus - Looss 1899 (Digenea): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 558]. 
   Haematoloechus nicolasi (Digenea): [Sp nov, Mexico, Parasite of Rana
   zweifeli (Amphibia), p. 556; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15401003538
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15401003539
DT Article
TI Helminths of the common opossum Didelphis marsupialis (Didelphimorphia:
   Didelphidae), with a checklist of helminths parasitizing marsupials from
   Peru.
AU Chero, Jhon D. (cristhian-5645@hotmail.com) 
   Saez, Gloria
   Mendoza-Vidaurre, Carlos
   Iannacone, Jose
   Cruces, Celso L.
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 88
IS 3
PS 560-571
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 6
AB Between May and November 2015, 8 specimens of Didelphis marsupialis
   Linnaeus, 1758 (Didelphimorphia: Didelphidae) collected in San Martin,
   Peru were examined for the presence of helminths. A total of 582
   helminths representing 11 taxa were identified (2 digeneans and 9
   nematodes). Five new host records and 4 species of nematodes
   (Gongylonemoides marsupialis (Vaz & Pereira, 1934) Freitas & Lent, 1937,
   Trichuris didelphis Babero, 1960, Viannaia hamata Travassos, 1914 and
   Viannaia viannaia Travassos, 1914) are added to the composition of the
   helminth fauna of the marsupials in this country. Further, a checklist
   of all available published accounts of helminth parasites reported from
   Peru is provided. To date, a total of 38 helminth parasites have been
   recorded. Digeneans have the highest species richness in number and
   percentage (n = 19, 50%), followed by nematodes (n = 17, 45%) and
   acanthocephalans (n = 2, 5%). The parasites with the highest number of
   records were the digeneans Plagiorchis didelphidis (Parona, 1896)
   Stossich, 1904 (n = 4) and Rhopalias coronatus Kifune & Uyema, 1982 (n =
   4) and the nematode Aspidodera sp. (n = 4). Additional sampling in this
   country will probably increase the richness of the helminthological
   inventory of this group of mammals.(C)2017 Universidad Nacional Autonoma
   de Mexico,Instituto de Biologia.
C1 Chero, Jhon D.; Univ Nacl Federico Villarreal, Fac Ciencias Nat &
   Matemat, Jr Rio Chepen 290, Lima, 15007, Peru, Peru.
EM cristhian-5645@hotmail.com
RI Iannacone, Jose/Q-8179-2019
OI Iannacone, Jose/0000-0003-3699-4732; CHERO DE LA CRUZ, JHON
   DARLY/0000-0003-3633-1365; Cruces Chancahuana, Celso
   Luis/0000-0003-1044-0862; SAEZ FLORES, GLORIA MARIA/0000-0001-9093-0065

   Mexico: Melpomene chamela sp. nov. (female) from Jalisco and Melpomene
   solisi sp. nov. (male and female) from Nuevo Leon, as well as the female

   (Pangaeus) docilis (Walker), P (Pangaeus) moestus (Stal), Pangaeus
   (Homaloporus) punctilinea (Froeschner), and P (Pangaeus) quinquespinosus
   (Froeschner). A list of the species of Pangaeus that have been recorded

   given. (C) 2017 Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Instituto de

DT Article
TI First record of Brachylaima (Trematoda: Brachylaimidae) in Salvator
   merianae (Squamata: Teiidae).
AU Fedatto-Bernardon, Fabiana (faimledato@gmail.com) 
   Dutra-Vieira, Thaina
   Muller, Gertrud
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 88
IS 3
PS 765-768
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Twenty-four gastrointestinal tracts of Salvator merianae were examined
   for helminths research. Immature forms of Brachylaima sp. were
   identified with a prevalence of 4.16%. This is the first occurrence the
   Brachylaimidae for this host species in Brazil and in South America
   since the previous records of Brachylaima sp. in lizards were known only
   from Europe and Eurasia. (C) 2017 Universidad Nacional Autonoma de
   Mexico, Instituto de Biologia.

TI Four new Coleophora Huebner, 1822 species from the Iberian Peninsula
   (Lepidoptera: Coleophoridae).
AU Tabell, J. (jukka.tabell@phnet.fi) 
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 45
IS 179
PS 385-402
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new Coleophora Hobner, 1822 species, C. septembra Tabell, sp. n.,
   C. tigris Tabell, sp. n., C. aragonensis Tabell, sp. n. and C. forcipata
   Tabell, sp. n. are described from the Iberian Peninsula. Habitus of the
   adults and the genitalia are illustrated. DNA barcodes are presented and
   compared to those of close relatives.

TI Notes on the Scythris punctivittella species-group, with description of
   a new species from Morocco (Lepidoptera: Scythrididae).
AU Nupponen, K. (Kari.Nupponen@kolumbus.fi) 
   Tabell, J.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 45
IS 179
PS 409-413
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Scythris bengti Nupponen & Tabell, sp. n. is described from Morocco. A
   pair of the new taxon, belonging to the punctivittella species-group,
   was collected in the High Atlas Mountains in late June, 2016. The
   external appearance and genitalia of both sexes of the new species are
   illustrated. The previously unknown male of S. atlasensis Bengtsson,
   1997 was discovered in the same site near the type locality of the
   taxon, and its genitalia are illustrated.

DT Article
TI On species related to Elachista deceptricula Staudinger, 1880 with
   descriptions of three new species (Lepidoptera: Elachistidae).
AU Kaila, L. (lauri.kaila@helsinki.fi) 
   Nupponen, K.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 45
IS 179
PS 415-428
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of Palearctic Elachista species similar to E. deceptricula
   Staudinger, 1880 is revised. Five species are treated: E. spumella
   Caradja, 1920, E. deceptricula Staudinger, Elachista athroa Kaila, sp.
   n. from Turkey, E. conferta Kaila sp. n. from Spain, and E. sagara Kaila
   sp. n. from Kyrgyzstan. Lectotype is designated for E. spumella Caradja.
   These species are assigned to the Elachista dispilella complex sensu
   Kaila in Elachista subgenera Aphelosetia. The E. dispilella complex now
   comprises 24 species.
C1 Kaila, L.; Univ Helsinki, Finnish Museum Nat Hist, Helsinki, FI-00014,
   Finland, Finland.
EM lauri.kaila@helsinki.fi

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe

DT Article
TI Contribution to the faunal study of the Tortricidae of Pelion Mountains
   (Greece) with description of Cydia magnesiae Trematerra & Colacci, sp n.
   (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae).
AU Trematerra, P. (trema@unimol.it) 
   Colacci, M.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 45
IS 179
PS 467-480
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The following contribution highlights an overview of the 50 species of
   Tortricidae captured on Pelion Mountain, in Central Greece, during
   several field trips by the authors. Eleven new species to the Greek
   fauna were recorded: Aethes margaritana, Eana incanana, Paramesia
   diffusana, Tosirips magyarus, Eudemis profundana, Ancylis badiana,
   Pelochrista modicana, Grapholita lathyrana, Grapholita tenebrosana,
   Dichrorampha alpigenana and Dichroranpha inconspiqua. Ceratoxanthis
   giansalottii, Endothenia apotomisana and Cydia pelionae are found to be
   endemic to Greece. Dichroranpha inconspiqua is reported for the first
   time in Europe. Cydia magnesiae Trematerra & Colacci, sp. n. is
   described as new.
C1 Trematerra, P.; Univ Molise, Dept Agr Environm & Food Sci, Via Sanctis
   1, Campobasso, I-86100, Italy, Italy.
EM trema@unimol.it
OI Trematerra, Pasquale/0000-0001-8584-0882; Colacci,
   Marco/0000-0002-9068-3049

SN 0300-5267

   Eurasia; Europe
DE Cydia magnesiae [Greece /  / New species]. 
   Dichrorampha inconspicua [Europe /  / New record]. 
   Tortricidae [Greece / Pelion Mountains / Faunal list; new record;
   systematics].

DT Article
TI On the fauna of the Coleophoridae of Mexico (Lepidoptera:
   Coleophoridae).
AU van der Wolf, H.W. (h.vanderwolf@onsnet.nu) 
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 45
IS 179
PS 481-495
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB 16 new species are described from Mexico: Coleophora papalotontli van
   der Wolf, sp. n., C. powelli van der Wolf, sp. n., C. saltoella van der
   Wolf, sp. n., C. tehuacanella van der Wolf, sp. n., C. coahuila van der
   Wolf, sp. n., C. popoloca van der Wolf, sp. n., C. bajacalsur van der
   Wolf, sp. n., C. penicillata van der Wolf, sp. n., C. pueblana van der
   Wolf, sp. n., C. catavinae van der Wolf, sp. n., C. puntaprietae van der
   Wolf, sp. nov., C. yagul van der Wolf, sp. n., C. bajacaliforniae van
   der Wolf, sp. n., C. iztac van der Wolf, sp. n., C. incerta van der
   Wolf, sp. n. and C. mexicacopa van der Wolf, sp. n. Of C. yagul the
   foodplant is given and the larval case described and illustrated. The
   female genitalia of C. mexicana Landry, 1994 are described and
   illustrated for the first time. C. versurella Zeller, 1849 is reported
   from Mexico for the first time.

   described, Female genitalia, p. 482].

   (Lepidoptera: Geometridae).

   Lindt, A.

VL 45
IS 179
PS 521-528
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Neotropical emerald geometrid genus Tachyphyle Butler, 1881 as
   revised by PITKIN (1996), consists of fifteen described species. This
   article is aimed at presenting descriptions of two additional species,
   Tachyphyle nielseni Viidalepp & Lindt, sp. n. from Argentina which is
   similar to T. acuta Butler, 1881 and Tachyphyle selini Viidalepp &
   Lindt, sp. n. from Costa Rica and Ecuador, which is similar with T.
   undilineata (Warren, 1900). The adults and their male genitalia are
   illustrated.

DT Article
TI Spectrum of Pollen Stored by Melipona mandacaia (Smith, 1863) (
   Hymenoptera: Apidae, Meliponini) in an Urban Arid Landscape.
AU Carneiro-Neto, T.F.S. (thiagofs_10@hotmail.com) 
   Reboucas, P.O.
   Pereira, J.E.
   Duarte, P.M.
   Santos, M.H.L.C.
   Silva, G.C.
   Siqueira, K.M.M.
SO Sociobiology
VL 64
IS 3
PS 284-291
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The objective of this study was to identify the species of pollen
   supplying plants that constitute the trophic niche of Melipona mandacaia
   in an urban area in the Caatinga domain (a tropical arid landscape). The
   collection of pollen in the colonies was carried out every 15 days, from
   October 2014 to September 2015. The pollen was removed directly from the
   storage pots in three distinct colonies. A total of 24 samples were
   analyzed and compared with the reference pollen collection, pollen
   catalogs and specialized literature. For the quantitative analysis, at
   least 1000 pollen grains per sample were identified. A total of 39
   pollen types were identified, distributed in 17 botanical families,
   being one an indeterminate type. The most represented family was the
   Fabaceae (n = 16). The most frequent types were Leucaena leucocephala,
   Mimosa pudica and Melochia sp. There was a significant positive
   correlation between temperature and the number of pollen types
   throughout the study. Relative humidity and rainfall were abiotic
   variables that did not present a significant correlation. The
   rarefaction curve showed that probably most of the pollen types
   collected by the bees studied were sampled, since the accumulation curve
   showed a progressive tendency to stabilization, indicating that there
   was sample adequacy of the pollen types. The analysis of similarity
   revealed a high sharing of pollen sources between colonies.
C1 Carneiro-Neto, T.F.S.; Univ Estado Bahia, Dept Tecnol & Ciencias
   Sociais, Rua Edgar Chastinet S-N, Juazeiro, BA, BR-48905680 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM thiagofs_10@hotmail.com
RI Oliveira-Reboucas, Patricia/L-2308-2018
OI Oliveira-Reboucas, Patricia/0000-0002-3986-7045; de Souza Carneiro Neto,
   Thiago Francisco/0000-0002-6026-4425
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 0361-6525
BD Nutrition; Diet; Ecology; Ecological niche; Habitat; Terrestrial
   habitat; Abiotic factors; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Melipona mandacaia [Food plants /  / Pollen feeding; pollen diversity
   spectrum] [Resource partitioning /  / ] [Forest and woodland / Caatinga
   habitat / ] [Abiotic factors / Environmental conditions / ] [Brazil /
   Bahia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Apoidea,
   Apidae
OR Melipona mandacaia (Apidae).

DT Article
TI Museum archives revisited: Central Asiatic hawkmoths reveal
   exceptionally high late Pliocene species diversification (Lepidoptera,
   Sphingidae).
AU Hundsdoerfer, Anna K. (anna.hundsdoerfer@senckenberg.de) 
   Paeckert, Martin
   Kehlmaier, Christian
   Strutzenberger, Patrick
   Kitching, Ian J.
SO Zoologica Scripta
VL 46
IS 5
PS 552-570
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 3
U2 12
AB Three high-elevation Hyles species of Central Asia have proven difficult
   to sample, and thus, only a limited number of specimens are available
   for study. Ancient DNA techniques were applied to sequence two
   mitochondrial genes from historic' museum specimens of Hyles gallii,
   Hyles renneri and Hyles salangensis to elucidate the phylogenetic
   relationships of these species. This approach enabled us to include the
   holotypes and paratypes. The status of H.salangensis as a species
   endemic to a mountain range north of Kabul in Afghanistan is confirmed
   by this study. It is most closely related to Hyles nicaea and H.gallii,
   and quite distant from the clade comprising the species from Hyles
   vespertilio to Hyles tithymali, despite this group and H.salangensis
   both completely lacking an arolium on the pretarsus. Our results show
   that the samples assigned to H.renneri and Hyles livornica tatsienluica
   are conspecific and so we reinstate Hyles tatsienluica stat. nov. as the
   valid name for this species and synonymize H.renneri syn. nov. with it.
   This study shows that the distribution range postulated for
   H.tatsienluica extends from Nepal well into the mountains of
   south-western China. The distribution ranges of H.livornica and
   H.tatsienluica overlap. The study confirms the previously proposed
   synonymies of Hyles nepalensis, Hyles gallii intermedia and Hyles gallii
   tibetanica with H.gallii. Extensive species sampling (over 80% of Hyles
   species) in this study allowed additional analyses. The dated phylogeny
   reveals the global Hyles hawkmoth radiation to be much more recent than
   previously thought: it began in the Late Miocene and culminated in a
   Pleistocene burst of diversification in the Northern Hemisphere.
   Ancestral ranges of basal nodes were reconstructed as highly equivocal,
   but the Neotropics has the highest probability in the two oldest nodes.
   Although the origins of the Madagascan and Australian species also
   remain ambiguous, a large crown clade of fifteen species was
   reconstructed to have originated in the Palaearctic. The wide
   distribution ranges of the two migratory species, H.livornica and
   H.gallii, appear to blur any traces of the biogeographic origin of the
   clades containing these species. Specialization in larval host plant use
   onto particular plant families from the ancestral condition polyphagous'
   may have led to an increased rate of speciation and phylogenetic
   diversification in three subgroups of Hyles (the Hawaiian clade, the
   Hyles centralasiae group and the Hyles euphorbiae complex).
C1 Hundsdoerfer, Anna K.; Senckenberg Nat Hist Collect Dresden,
   Konigsbrucker Landstr 159, Dresden, D-01109, Germany, Germany.
EM anna.hundsdoerfer@senckenberg.de
OI Hundsdoerfer, Anna/0000-0001-5594-4154; Strutzenberger,
   Patrick/0000-0003-3278-5693
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0300-3256
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; General
   morphology; Nutrition; Diet; Genetics; Evolution; Evolutionary
   adaptation; Ecology; Zoogeography
DE Hyles [General morphology /  / systematics] [Food plants /  / ]
   [Molecular genetics / Mt & ancient DNA sequences / ] [Divergence /  / ]
   [Origin of taxon /  / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Ecology /  / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Sphingoidea, Sphingidae
OR Hyles - Huebner 1819 (Sphingidae). 
   Hyles gallii - (von Rottemburg 1775) (Sphingidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Hyles gallii intermedia (Kirby 1837), p. 564; Senior synonym, Of Hyles
   gallii tibetanica Eichler 1971, p. 564; Senior synonym, Of Hyles
   nepalensis (Daniel 1961), p. 564]. 
   Hyles gallii intermedia - (Kirby 1837) (Sphingidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Hyles gallii (von Rottemburg 1775), p. 564]. 
   Hyles gallii tibetanica - Eichler 1971 (Sphingidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Hyles gallii (von Rottemburg 1775), p. 564]. 
   Hyles livornica - (Esper 1892) (Sphingidae): [Senior synonym, Of Hyles
   malgassica (Denso 1944), p. 564; Removal from synonymy, Hyles renneri
   Eitschberger, Danner & Surholt 1998, p. 563]. 
   Hyles livornica tatsienluica - (Oberthuer 1916) (Sphingidae): [Raised
   to, Hyles tatsienluica, p. 563]. 
   Hyles malgassica - (Denso 1944) (Sphingidae): [Junior synonym, Of Hyles
   livornica (Esper 1892), p. 564]. 
   Hyles nepalensis - (Daniel 1961) (Sphingidae): [Junior synonym, Of Hyles
   gallii (von Rottemburg 1775), p. 564]. 
   Hyles renneri - Eitschberger, Danner & Surholt 1998 (Sphingidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, With Hyles livornica (Esper 1892), p. 563]. 
   Hyles tatsienluica - (Oberthuer 1916) (Sphingidae): [Syn nov, Hyles
   renneri Eitschberger, Danner & Surholt 1998, p. 563; Raised from, Hyles
   livornica tatsienluica, p. 563]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15401001593

AN ZOOR15312083795
DT Article
TI Descriptions of new subspecies of cowries (Gastropoda: Cypraeidae).
AU Meyer, Christopher P. (MeyerC@si.edu) 
   Lorenz, Felix
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 16
PS 5-27
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Eight new subspecies of cowries (Cypraeidae) are described. They are
   characterized mainly by genetic data, but also in most cases, rather
   subtle conchological differences. Lyncina Pentricuhts johnclarki n. ssp.
   from Christmas Island differs by an average COI pairwise difference of
   2.05 % from the nominate Pacific subspecies. The shell of the new
   subspecies is broader and higher, the distribution of basal callus
   differs. Palmachtsta ziczac vzac n. ssp. from Thailand has a
   characteristic finer y-shaped zig-zag-pattern and apart from other
   subtle features, its average COI pairwise difference from other
   populations of the species is 8.4 (Yo. Bistolida myelitis jomi n. ssp.
   from the eastern Indian Ocean has more numerous teeth, and a 7.1 %
   average COI pairwise difference separating it from the nominate Pacific
   subspecies. Ransionella punctata bridgesi n. ssp. and R. p. conleyi n.
   ssp. closely resemble other populations of the species conchologically,
   but their average COI pairwise differences of 9.3 % and 3.3 %
   respectively, support their recognition as separate subspecies.
   Cribrarula abaliena etypersica n. ssp. from the northwestern Indian
   Ocean has an average COI pairwise difference of 2.1 % from its sister
   lineages. The shells resemble a. ganteri and differ only in subtle
   details. Purpuradusta limbriata ipso/ha n. ssp. from Cocos Keeling and
   Christmas Islands differs from its sister lineages by subtle features of
   the dorsal banding, the aperture, the formation or the anterior
   columellar teeth and an average COI pairwise difference of 3.2 %. The
   name Murrill('scurra occidua n. ssp. replaces the improper usage of
   scurra, for Indian Ocean populations. It differs from its Pacific
   sisters by a more inflated shell, narrower netting, denser marginal
   spots and a different structure of the extremities. The average COI
   pairwise difference from the nominate scurra (12.8 %) is exceptionally
   high.
C1 Meyer, Christopher P.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB
   37012,MRC 163, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM MeyerC@si.edu

DT Article
TI A new subspecies of Bistolida stolida (LINNAEUS 1758) from Queensland
   (Gastropoda: Cypraeidae).
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix@cowries.info) 
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 16
PS 47-57
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bistolida stolida lorrainae n. ssp. from Queensland differs from the
   conchologically most similar sympatric B. brevidentwa fluentans by the
   number of columellar versus labral teeth, and other subtle shell
   features. Its less thickened teeth, lack of posterior callus, reduced
   blotching and spotting, separates B. s. lorrainae from other subspecies
   of B. stolida. The Australian taxa of the stolida species complex are
   briefly discussed.

TI The Philippine population of Austrasiatica langfordi (KURODA 1938)
   (Gastropoda: Cypraeidae).

   Chiapponi, Marco

PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Austrasiatica langfordi poppeorum n. ssp. from the Philippines differs
   from the nominate subspecies by the oval instead of pyriform shape, the
   finer dorsal pattern, by a paler, evenly distributed coloration of the
   basal callus, as well as by an angular instead of rounded lett. margin.
   The morphology and geographical distribution of A. langfordi and other
   deep water species is discussed.

DT Article
TI The most bizarre Cowry that ever lived: Gisortia megaloptera n. sp.
   (Gastropoda: Cypraeidae).
AU Lorenz, Felix (felix@cowries.info) 
SO Acta Conchyliorum
VL 16
PS 87-99
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Gisortia Megaloptera n. sp. is described from the Ypresian, early Eocene
   of Gan, France. It differs from the younger G. coombii (J. DE C. SOWERBY
   in DIXON 1850) from the Lutetian Eocene by the structure of the
   posterior extremity, the stronger development of lateral flanges and
   protuberances, by the presence of a prominent dorsal wing, and numerous
   other conchological aspects. The extreme features of the holotype are
   backed up by several less bizarre specimens of the same provenance,
   which are tentatively assigned to the new species.

DT Article
TI An Update of the Goblin Spider Genus Birabenella Grismado, 2010
   (Araneae: Oonopidae), with the Description of Three New Species.
AU Piacentini, Luis N.
   Grismado, Cristian J.
   Ramirez, Martin J.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3883
PS 1-17
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomy of the poorly known South American goblin spider genus
   Birabenella Grismado (Araneae: Oonopidae) is updated in light of
   recently collected material. Three new species are described: B.
   kamanchaca, from northern Chile, B. portai, from northwestern Argentina,
   and B. chincha, from southern Peru, where the genus is reported for the
   first time. The diagnosis of the genus is updated; the presence of the
   ventral digitiform projection on the male copulatory bulb in the three
   newly described species supports this character as a putative
   synapomorphy for the genus. Additionally, all species in this genus
   possess unipectinate tarsal claws. Preliminary observations indicate
   that there is some degree of variability in tarsal organ morphology.
C1 Piacentini, Luis N.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat Bernardino Rivadavia,
   Div Aracnol, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Birabenella [South America /  / Distribution; systematics] [Peru /  /
   New record]. 
   Birabenella chincha [Peru /  / New species]. 
   Birabenella kamanchaca [Chile /  / New species]. 
   Birabenella portai [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae

   record]. 
   Birabenella chincha (Araneae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 14]. 
   Birabenella kamanchaca (Araneae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 7]. 
   Birabenella portai (Araneae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 10].

DT Article
TI Ancient lakes, Pleistocene climates and river avulsions structure the
   phylogeography of a large but little-known rock scorpion from the Mojave
   and Sonoran deserts.
AU Graham, Matthew R. (grahamm@easternct.edu) 
   Wood, Dustin A.
   Henault, Jonathan A.
   Valois, Zachary J.
   Cushing, Paula E.
SO Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 122
IS 1
PS 133-146
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 1
U2 23
AB Recent syntheses of phylogeographical data from terrestrial animals in
   the Mojave and Sonoran deserts have revealed a complex history of
   geologic and climatic vicariance events. We studied the phylogeography
   of Smeringurus vachoni to see how vicariance events may have impacted a
   large, endemic rock scorpion. Additionally, we used the
   phylogeographical data to examine the validity of two subspecies of
   S.vachoni that were described using unconventional morphological
   characters. Phylogenetic, network and SAMOVA analyses indicate that
   S.vachoni consists of 11 clades mostly endemic to isolated desert
   mountain ranges. Molecular clock estimates suggest that clades
   diversified between the Miocene and early Pleistocene. Species
   distribution models predict a contraction of suitable habitat during the
   last glacial maximum. Landscape interpolations and Migrate-n analyses
   highlight areas of gene flow across the Colorado River. Smeringurus
   vachoni does not comprise two subspecies. Instead, the species
   represents at least 11 mitochondrial clades that probably diversified by
   vicariance associated with Pleistocene climate changes and formation of
   ancient lakes along the Colorado River corridor. Gene flow appears to
   have occurred from west to east across the Colorado River during
   periodic river avulsions.
C1 Graham, Matthew R.; Eastern Connecticut State Univ, Dept Biol, 83
   Windham St, Willimantic, CT, 06226, USA, USA.
EM grahamm@easternct.edu
OI Wood, Dustin/0000-0002-7668-9911
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences
SN 0024-4066
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Genetics; Evolution; Habitat;
   Terrestrial habitat; Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Zoogeography;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Smeringurus vachoni [Molecular genetics / Mt & nDNA sequences /
   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Desert habitat
   /  / ] [Climate and weather / Climate change / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Arizona /  / ] [California /  / ] [Nevada /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Smeringurus vachoni - Stahnke (Scorpiones): [Syn nov, Smeringurus
   vachoni immanis Soleglad 1972, p. 141]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15312082725

AN ZOOR15312084109
DT Article
TI Oncholaimus zhangi sp nov (Oncholaimidae, Nematoda) from the intertidal
   zone of the East China Sea.
AU Gao Qun
   Huang Yong (huangy@lcu.edu.cn) 
SO Chinese Journal of Oceanology and Limnology
VL 35
IS 5
PS 1212-1217
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A new species of free-living marine nematode is described from
   intertidal sediment of the East China Sea. The new species belongs to
   the Oncholaimidae family. Oncholaimus zhangi sp. nov. is characterized
   by males having a large ventral swelling situated just posterior to the
   middle of the tail, no precloacal papilla, and a row of 6-7 ventral
   genital setae. The tails of both males and females are similar, being
   conico-cylindrical in shape. The new species is distinguished from other
   closely related species by the presence of a prominent ventral swelling
   at the tail of males and a similar tail shape in both sexes. About 110
   valid species in this genus have been recorded to date.
C1 Huang Yong; Liaocheng Univ, Coll Life Sci, Liaocheng, 252059, China,
   China.
EM huangy@lcu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0254-4059

   1215].

DT Article
TI The first fossil Dipsocoridae found in the early Eocene amber of France
   (Hemiptera: Heteroptera).
AU Hartung, Viktor
   Garrouste, Romain
   Nel, Andre (viktor.hartung@smnk.de) 
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 16
IS 7
PS 715-720
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Cryptostemma eocenica sp. nov., the first fossil representative of the
   family Dipsocoridae (Heteroptera: Dipsocoromorpha), is described from
   Eocene amber of France on the basis of a single macropterous female. The
   specimen is very modern in appearance, demonstrating the remarkable
   morphological stability of this family since 53 Ma. Its generic
   affinities are difficult to estimate because the modern genera are
   mostly separated by male genitalia or female internal structures. (C)
   2017 Academie des sciences. Published by Elsevier Masson SAS.
C1 Nel, Andre; Sorbonne Univ, Museum Natl Hist Nat, 57 Rue Cuvier,CP 50,
   Paris, F-75005, France, France.

   Palaeogene

DT Article
TI First mammal of Gondwanan lineage in the early Eocene of India.
AU Kapur, Vivesh V. (viveshkapur@gmail.com) 
   Das, Debasis P.
   Bajpai, Sunil
   Prasad, Guntupalli V.R.
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 16
IS 7
PS 721-737
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Based on well-preserved lower dentition, a new adapisoriculid from the
   Cambay Shale Formation (basal Eocene, [approximately]54.5 Ma) in the
   open cast lignite mine of Vastan, Gujarat State, western India, is
   described. Indolestes kalamensis gen. et sp. nov adds significantly to
   the diversity of basal eutherians from Vastan as it represents a family
   hitherto not known from the Eocene of the Indian Subcontinent.
   Phylogenetic analysis suggests that Indolestes is derived relative to
   Deccanolestes and Afrodon, but primitive relative to the European
   adapisoriculids Bustylus and Adapisoriculus. The new data from the early
   Eocene provide evidence for continued survival of a Gondwanan mammal
   lineage following the Deccan volcanic activity (Cretaceous-Paleogene
   transition) in the Indian Subcontinent. (C) 2017 Academie des sciences.
   Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Kapur, Vivesh V.; Birbal Sahni Inst Palaeosci, 53 Univ Rd, Lucknow,
   Uttar Pradesh, 226007, India, India.
EM viveshkapur@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1631-0683

   Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene

   Indolestes kalamensis [Gujarat /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ].

DT Article
TI A new Ruscinian site in Europe: Baza-1 (Baza basin, Andalusia, Spain).
AU Ros-Montoya, Sergio
   Martinez-Navarro, Bienvenido (bienvenido.martinez@icrea.cat) 
   Espigares, Maria-Patrocinio
   Guerra-Merchan, Antonio
   Manuel Garcia-Aguilar, Jose
   Pinero, Pedro
   Rodriguez-Rueda, Ainoa
   Agusti, Jordi
   Oms, Oriol
   Palmqvist, Paul
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 16
IS 7
PS 746-761
PD Sep 2017
PY 2017
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Guadix-Baza depression (southeastern Spain) preserves one of the
   best continental Plio-Pleistocene records of the European continent. The
   new site, Baza-1, is the first Ruscinian locality with fauna of large
   vertebrates known in the basin. During the summer seasons of 2001, 2002,
   2015 and 2016, systematic excavations were undertaken in the site over
   an area of 25 m2, which provided > 400 fossil remains of Ruscinian
   mammals. The faunal assemblage is diverse, comprising 17 genera.
   Rodentia are represented by Ruscinomys sp., Apocricetus barrierei,
   Debruijnimys julii, Apodemus gorafensis, Castillomys gracilis,
   Occitanomys cf. brailloni, Paraethomys meini, Paraethomys aff. abaigari,
   Stephanomys cordii, Trilophomys cf. castroi and Eliomys aff.
   intermedius. Large mammals are represented by two proboscideans, Anancus
   arvernensis and Mammut borsoni, the rhino Stephanorhinus sp. cf. S.
   jeanvireti, the equid cf. Hipparion sp., two bovids, a large sized
   Alephis sp. and a small-to-middle sized Bovidae indet. (cf. Antilope
   sp.), and a middle sized deer, Cervinae indet. This record is completed
   by the presence of a chelonid, Testudinae indet. Biostratigraphic data
   from micro and macromammals suggest an age for the assemblage between 4
   and 4.5 Ma. (C) 2017 Academie des sciences. Published by Elsevier Masson
   SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Martinez-Navarro, Bienvenido; URV, IPHES, Campus Sescelades,Edifici W3,
   Tarragona, 43007, Spain, Spain.
EM bienvenido.martinez@icrea.cat

   Espigares, M.P./L-6084-2014; Ros-Montoya, Sergio/AAD-1749-2019
